turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What -- what are you doing?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I think you should feel like dancing at a time like this.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: C'mon.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Honey?  How did it go?  You didn't call me.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: He wasn't there.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I get to the restaurant and he's not there. I waited for forty- five minutes.  When I called his office, his secretary said they thought I had cancelled.  I had cancelled!  Then I get back to my office and <u>Aranson</u> is waiting for me and he knows <u>everything</u>.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Oh, honey.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: <u>Everything</u> -- that I've been talking to other people behind his back -- that's what he called me -- a back-stabber and a deceiver. To him and to the company. He called me a traitor in front of everybody and told me if I wanted to be a VP over at Lowenthal I might as well pack up and go -- only <u>Lowenthal never</u> <u>showed up for our lunch</u>!  It's like everybody got an anonymous poison-pen letter or some --  Do you smell smoke?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Honey -- I can't find those large- size Hefty trash bags!

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: There might be some extras in the garage.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Honey, it's not the end of the world.  You'll call Lowenthal tomorrow and find out it was just a mix-up.  And if he's not interested anymore, then you'll find another company to go to maybe even your own.  You are free now, you are independent.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I'm <u>fired</u>.  I'm unemployed.  Is that your idea of negotiating from a position of strength?  Clearly any potential employers have been warned to back off!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: That's not the case.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Someone blew the whistle.  Someone hates me.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Boy, you really buckle under a little pressure, don't you?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: This is for the best, you know it is.  Why do my socks keep disappearing!

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: "Honey, I'm a zombie, I don't know whether I'm coming or going."

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: You're even sadder and more burnt- out than I thought.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I am so sick to death of hearing <u>your</u> opinion of my state of mind, what <u>you</u> think is for my own good. Without me you'd still be twirling a baton at U.C. Santa Barbara. <u>You're</u> the final straw on this back, baby!

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Who was that?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I'm having the floor fixed,

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: And what was that neighbor guy doing here?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Philip, what are <u>you</u> doing here?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Look, I think we should work things out.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I was having a bad day -- I lost that job, I was dependent on other people, I was let down --

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: There's always an excuse, isn't there?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I think it's time I came home now.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: That's not a decision for you to make on your own.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: No, Philip, I don't want you coming back here.  And if you want to talk to me -- <u>call</u>.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: This is my house.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Oh God.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Yeah -- we know him.  He's been hanging around the house.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Should I come home when I'm finished there?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: We'll talk in the morning.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: It's been on the market a while, hasn't it?

turns.speaker: REAL-ESTATE LADY
turns.text: Not very long.  There have been a couple of bids already.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Because it caught my eye when it was in a higher price bracket in the listings.

turns.speaker: REAL-ESTATE LADY
turns.text: Oh, yes, well, you know, when developers remodel a house they often overestimate their costs at first.  It's not like it's been marked down or anything.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Just reduced.

turns.speaker: REAL-ESTATE LADY
turns.text: Sometimes they prefer a quicker return on their investment.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: This is a terrific entrance hall, What a welcoming feeling.

turns.speaker: REAL-ESTATE LADY
turns.text: Isn't it?

turns.speaker: REAL-ESTATE LADY
turns.text: You'll see that there's really much more space than the average three bedroom.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Oh, space!  -- You said the right thing.

turns.speaker: REAL-ESTATE LADY
turns.text: How large is your brood?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Two -- three if you count the husband.

turns.speaker: REAL-ESTATE LADY
turns.text: We must <u>always</u> count the husband. By my count there've been... four. But I still live in hope.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: God, your sister's really hot.

turns.speaker: NEIL'S FRIEND #1
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Let's follow 'em.

turns.speaker: NEIL'S FRIEND #1
turns.text: What for, dickweed?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: It's fun.

turns.speaker: NEIL'S FRIEND #1
turns.text: Grow up, Dreyer.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Shit!

turns.speaker: NEIL'S FRIEND #1
turns.text: Put it out, man!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Are we gonna buy this house?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Do you have enough money?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Dad, we can't decide unless Rudolf gets to look too!

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Would you mind if Rudolf had a look too?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Okay!  We have TV!  We can all get stupid again!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What about cable?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: We'll get cable when the cable company is good and ready -- you think you can survive till then?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: All right, who ate the last piece of cheesecake?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I didn't.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Neil, do you mind?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Rudolf?  C'mere, Rudolf!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: All right then, if I have to go to school then I'd better go.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Why?  I just read your report card.  What's the point?  Stay home, watch some television, we'll get "Mad" magazine delivered.  What kind of report card do you call this?!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I've been going through a lot of personal crap, all right?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Oh really?  <u>You've</u> been going through a lot of personal crap. You, Princess Di and Madonna?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: If you want that baseball jacket for your birthday, Neil, learn to cough a little more realistically.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I have a cold.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What did the thermometer say?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: The thermometer's broken.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Y'know what?  I'm ready to cancel our trip.  I really am. I've had it.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: And I can't help having a cold.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What d'you want me to do, Neil? I've told you we'll get another dog.  What does EVERYONE want me to do?  You want to move back? Huh?  Would you like that?  Should we all just pack up again and MOVE BACK?!

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Hiya, sport.  Where'd you come from, huh?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Can we keep him?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: A <u>man</u> started the fire.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Neil, goddamn it, you're not five years old!

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: You knew a second ago.  <u>Who</u> started it?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: -- A man.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Do you see a man?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: No man!  <u>Go to your room</u>.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I thought I was supposed to stay in my room.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Get on the other side of that.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: And this -- is the master bedroom.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Oh yeah?  Where's the bed?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Right over here.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Is it a king or a queen?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: It's a double.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Even better.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Even cosier.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: That's right -- you got the bill this morning.  I put it on your desk.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Thank you -- how efficient of you.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Promise?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Promise.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I'd like that.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Would you?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: What the hell.  What is this?  A joke?

turns.speaker: ROBBERY DETECTIVE
turns.text: No joke, Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Where's the guy we saw in the beginning -- what's his name...?

turns.speaker: ROBBERY DETECTIVE
turns.text: Parker.  We found him knocked out in the can.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: If he was knocked out in the can how could be walking across the lobby?

turns.speaker: ROBBERY DETECTIVE
turns.text: Hey, I don't have answers for this. I just brought you down here because of the sword.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Am I supposed to believe that this guy got shot in the chest six times at point blank range and just got up and walked out?

turns.speaker: ROBBERY DETECTIVE
turns.text: You can believe what you want.  You saw the tape.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Lieutenant Bedsoe?

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Not now.  I'm busy.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Lieutenant?

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: What?  Who are you?  What do you want?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: My name is Jennifer Hillman.  I'm an archaeologist.  I read in the paper about the murder yesterday and I thought I should come talk to you.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Talk to me about what?

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: They appear to be authentic.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Why are people walking around New York with swords, dressed in mid evil clothing?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Well, technically it's not mid evil - - it's Renaissance.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: You didn't see this.  Understand?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Did you find a sword?  An old sword?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: Yeah -- how'd you know that?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: Hey Lieutenant, the boys in robbery have something I think you should look at.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: A tape from the surveillance camera at the First National Bank.  It was robbed this morning.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Really?  I want to make sure that I understand what you're telling me, Greley.  A crime was committed in New York City?  That is news.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: The guy had a sword and was dressed like this guy.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: That's not all, Lieutenant.  Wait until you see the tape.  It's unbelievable.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: I'd like you to see this.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Good -- also, give it to the papers and TV.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: Y'know, the guys in robbery are gonna get kind of upset.  We're stepping on their toes of this one.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Tough.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: It's not a homicide, Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: This ties in with Nash.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: We don't have any proof of that.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: I don't need proof.  I know it.  Send it out.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Anything from the bank?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: We sent the prints we lifted from the counter at the bank to the State computers, the FBI and interpol. Nothing.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: He had to come from somewhere.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: I think it was England.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE GRELEY
turns.text: I asked the State Department to check with our Embassies and Interpol to see if there were any similar occurrences like the bank.  Two weeks ago in London Charles Redder from the Bronx was mugged in Hyde Park.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: I'm in the middle of an interrogation, Captain.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Interrogation's over, Bedsoe.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Cut him loose.  The D.A. says you ain't got shit on this guy.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: You don't understand.  About seven years ago we found the body of a guy named Vasilnic in Jersey.  A week later in the parking lot of Madison Square Garden we found Iman Fasil. Three days after that Luman Castageer was found in an alley.  The fourth body we've never been able to identify.  All four men died from decapitation.  Nash was our primary suspect -- but he disappeared.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: It's circumstantial.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: For Chrissake!  Gimme a break.  The guy disappears for seven years and as soon as he comes back it starts again.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: I see your point, Bedsoe, but I have to look at this from the law's point of view.  There's something missing here.  It's something I'm sure you've come across many times in your career.  It's called evidence.  Get me a murder weapon with his fingerprints on it.  Find me an eye witness.  Dig up a motive.  Until then we don't have a case against him.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Detective Bedsoe.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Congratulations.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: When did you get back?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: A few days ago.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: That's what I figured.  Well, I have a little home coming present for you.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Where were you last night around nine?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I already told you.  I took a walk.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Tell me again.  Where'd you go?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Central Park.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Doesn't it scare you walk through the park at night?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: No.  I don't scare easy.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Where have you been for the last seven years?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Around.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: And Brenda?

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: She was a good woman.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: You didn't bring me here to talk about her.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: I brought you here to talk about him. Do you know him?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: He doesn't look familiar -- but then he'd probably be easier to identity with his head.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: I'm gonna nail you, Nash.  That's a promise.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Is that it?

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: No.  I'm telling you right now, the next person's head that comes off is gonna be yours.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Lieutenant, you're really frightening me.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Get outta here.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Good evening, Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: No -- it isn't.  A cop died today and the other is barely holding on.  I want some answers, Nash.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I'm sorry about that -- but I had nothing to do with it.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: That doesn't mean you don't know what's going on.  You're connected to this guy somehow.  He's after you -- just like the others were.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: It's late.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Seven years ago I interviewed a guy. He said he saw two men fighting in an alley with swords.  One cut off the others head.  He shot the surviving guy twenty times and he got right back up and stabbed him.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Maybe he was a lousy shot.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Most people would show some sign of fear with a gun in their face.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Most people are afraid of death.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Yes -- I think it is.

turns.speaker: BEDSOE
turns.text: Hey -- somebody want to gimme a hand here?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: You'll have no need for that, Highlander.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Since we hardly know each other, I'm sure you'll understand if I hold one to it for awhile.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Caution shows wisdom.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: I know that weapon.  It belonged to Juan Romeriz.  He's dead?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: No.  He was my brother.  He died at anothers hand.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: We too are brothers, Macleod.  In fact, you have more family than you think.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Thomas Cavenaugh.  I am a teacher of sorts.  Like Romeriz I help those newly acquainted with our life.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I learned my fill from Romeriz.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Indeed you did.  And now it is time for you to pass on to others what you learned from him.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: The prize?  So much blood so that in the end the one that remains will be mortal again.  So much pain so that the winner can grow old and have children.  The prize hardly seems worth the cost of it.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: There will be more to the prize than that.  Power will come with it -- and it must be used for good.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: The days of magic are ending.  The world is changing.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Aye -- yet one such as I who has wandered this world for nearly nine centuries can remember back to other days of change.  Days of Robin of the Hood and Arthur Pendragon.  They were real enough once, but they drifted into men's dreams and became legend - - as we shall do one day.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: You cannot run from your destiny, Conner.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Perhaps -- but if I must face it, let it find me, for I shall search for it no more.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Must you do that?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Sing.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: It is a beautiful day.  I am merely enjoying it.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Can't you enjoy it quietly?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Are you always this pleasant?  You know what you're problem is?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Life.  You've stopped living it.  You look, but you do not see.  You listen but, you do not hear.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I hear you.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: What else?  What else do you hear right now?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: The river.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: That's all?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Do you not hear the wind in the trees?  The songs of the birds.  The horses breath?  There is a whole world around you. Alive.  Living.  Feel it -- become part of it.  Live your life, Highlander.  It's going to be a long one.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: That is what bothers me.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: I see.  You don't care about life anymore.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I'm leaving.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Leaving what?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: England.  There is nothing for me here anymore.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: And what do you think you will find in another land?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Maybe myself.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Then it's worth the journey.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Thank you, Thomas.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: For being a friend when I needed one. I hope our paths cross again.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: I'm sure they will.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: As friends -- always as friends.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: We cannot write our destiny, Macleod. In the end it could be you and me.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: That is a thought that doesn't please me.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: If it came down to it what would you do?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I do not know.  I pray that I shall never have to raise my sword against one that I call friend.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: You're looking a wee bit green, Thomas.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: The sea and I don't agree with each other.  Where we off to?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: France.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: How long is the voyage?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Not long.  We should arrive in the morning.  Are you going to be alright?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Me?  Of course.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: What are we doing here?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Living.  Remember?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: You may be living -- but this suit is killing me.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: To ask her to dance.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: She's the King's cousin.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Then she should be an excellent dancer.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: What worries you?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: You.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: You've been seeing her for over a month now.  Have you learned nothing from the past?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I've learned that a man can only go so along living alone.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: So, you do this for yourself?  What about her?  You cannot not have a relationship, Macleod.  You've told me of your wife, Heather, and how you loved her. Romeriz warned you then, but you would not listen.  You watched her grow old and die -- and there was nothing you could do.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: That was two hundred and fifty years ago -- and the pain still scars your heart.  Would you live that pain again?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: No.  What am I to do?

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: The only thing you can do.  You must end it.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: It's done.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: I'll go first.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: No -- I will.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: I stood up first.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: That doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: You always get to go first.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: You can go first.

turns.speaker: CAVANAUGH
turns.text: No -- after you.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: It will be a good harvest this year.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Can you really tell from doing that?

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I think you just like to eat dirt.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: I think my Sarah fancies you, Conner.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: She's a treasure she is.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: She'll soon be of age.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Your words are kind and they flatter me -- but I think of her as a sister. Besides, you hardly know me.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: I know that for six months you've worked hard and asked for little. That you're a good and honest man. What more need I know?

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: This cannot be.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: It is.  Do not ask me how.  I do not know.  I must leave, for if I stayed others would surely hear of this and worse than they will come.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Agreed.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I would like to say goodbye.

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: VIEIRA
turns.text: How comes it your are not afraid?

turns.speaker: HOODED MAN
turns.text: Would'st you harm one who comes to aid you?

turns.speaker: HOODED MAN
turns.text: I've come to strike a bargain with you.  I wish to learn the power of changing.

turns.speaker: VIEIRA
turns.text: And what would'st I gain from this bargain?

turns.speaker: HOODED MAN
turns.text: Your life.

turns.speaker: VIEIRA
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: VIEIRA
turns.text: We had a bargain.  You promised.

turns.speaker: HOODED MAN
turns.text: I lied.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Aye?

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Where do you go when your mind drifts?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Different places.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: The past?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Sometimes.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Why is it you never talk to me about Scotland -- your life there.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Because it's the past -- and things that are in the past are best left there.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I cannot stay.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I'm leaving in the morning.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Leaving?  For how long?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: You'll no see me again.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I cannot explain.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Do you love me, Conner?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Then take me with you.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Where I'm going you cannot follow.

turns.speaker: ISABELLE
turns.text: Why are you doing this?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Because, it's for the best.  There are somethings that are better left unexplained.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Electro magnetic soundings indicate we've only got a few inches of rock left before we reach the main chamber.

turns.speaker: REPORTER
turns.text: Any idea how big the cavern is on the other side?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Huge.

turns.speaker: REPORTER
turns.text: What are you hoping to find inside?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: You guys are from the British museum, right?

turns.speaker: REPORTER
turns.text: No -- we're from Strange facts and mysteries.  It's a syndicated show out of..

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Paul.  I thought we agreed.  No press.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: My name is Jennifer Hillman.  I was at the police station earlier today--

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I remember you.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I was wondering if I could talk to you?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Are you a cop?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: No.  I'm an archaeologist.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: To talk to you.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I don't think we have anything to talk about, Miss Hillman.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Corpses?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Yes.  We found another man outside a site we were working at in Scotland.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: In the highlands?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Yes.  How did you know?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: A lucky guess.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I don't think so -- but then, maybe you've can guess how a guy with a sword could rob the First national Bank this afternoon -- and get shot six times in the chest by the guard and still get up and walk out?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: He was wearing a bullet proof vest.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Bullet proof vests don't bleed.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: You got me.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Why do I feel that you know what's going on?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Are you the type of person who takes advice, Miss Hillman?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: If it's good advice.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: This is.  Go home.  Stay out of this.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Why?  What's going on?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Where did you get it?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: It's mine.  It's been in my family for years.  It belonged to my great, great, great grandmother.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: You're hurt.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I'll be fine.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: What's going on?  Why did he call you Macleod?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: Because it's my name.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Then who's Russell Nash?

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: I don't know anymore.

turns.speaker: MCCLEOD
turns.text: You are a very persistent woman, Miss Hillman.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Jennifer.
